newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss private bank keen on Europe stocks.
newsitem.headline: Swiss private bank keen on Europe stocks.

text.p: Swiss private bank Pictet & Cie said on Thursday that it favoured a return to European and British stocks, a downsizing of Japanese shares and a reduction in fixed income bonds exposure for asset allocation.

In its latest investment strategy report, the Geneva bank said it favoured a sizeable chunk of its asset allocation -- 25 percent -- in cash and cautioned against low bond yields and the current valuation of stock markets.
In equities, the bank said it was moving away from Japanese shares in favour of European stocks.

Pictet & Cie said Japan had been "desperately disappointing" with domestic investors reluctant to put their money in Tokyo shares and that non-European shares looked expensive in the absence of an upgrading of corporate earnings forecasts.
But it saw sweet pickings in European and British stocks.
"The expected return to economic growth in Europe suggests that corporate profits could register some surprisingly sharp increases," it said.
"We recommend a smaller proportion than usual in equities, except in Europe where a non-inflationary recovery stands a good chance of taking place next year."

In emerging markets, Pictet & Cie said an influx of foreign money was behind a surge in Russian stocks since the start of this year. But it said investors were nervous over never-ending reform of tax laws and banks cutting off corporate credit lines.
In Poland, the bank said foreign investors were unsettled by inflation and were taking a wait-and-see appraoch before taking up stock positions for the year-end.
In Latin America, Pictet & Cie predicted a rally on Chile's market from its current rock-bottom levels and favoured interest-rate-sensitive stocks such as utilities and banks.
Pictet & Cie was bullish about Mexico provided that buyers stick to a sectoral approach. In Brazil, it favoured retailing and capital goods companies.

The bank said its current global dollar portfolio with a medium-risk profile allocated roughly 40 percent in equities, 30 percent in bonds, five percent in commodities-related assets and the remaining in cash.
The same portfolio with a low-risk profile had 20 percent in equities, 45 percent in bonds, 32 percent in cash and three percent in commodities-related assets.
